awd_titl_txt: Robust and Scalable Volume Minimization-based Matrix Factorization for Sensing and Clustering
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on matrix factorization using a simplicial cone model, which has a wide variety of applications in remote sensing (particularly hyperspectral imaging), radio frequency sensing for dynamic spectrum access, clustering and topic modeling, and social network analysis, to name a few. The project focuses on robust and scalable computational tools for this model, using a convex hull volume minimization criterion. The motivation partially comes from a result that was recently obtained by the principal investigators, showing that unique factorization is possible under mild conditions if one adopts the volume minimization criterion. These conditions are far more realistic than those required by existing approaches, suggesting that more challenging scenarios and even new application domains are within reach if only related optimization, robustness, and scalability challenges can be effectively addressed. This research will provide the computational underpinnings of these exciting developments. High-performance volume minimization software will be publicly released to enable researchers and practitioners to tackle new problems, handle much larger datasets, and boost performance in existing applications like hyperspectral imaging. On the education front, the project will help train a graduate student in cutting-edge computational engineering research, and will also help engage talented undergraduates through senior honors projects, introducing them to research and publication opportunities.  

In terms of theory and methods, key aspects of volume minimization-based matrix factorization are still poorly understood. The research will provide a set of high-performance computational tools rooted in deep understanding of the strengths and weaknesses of the original volume minimization criterion which promises exciting discoveries.  The research will evolve along the following synergistic thrusts: i) robust optimization algorithms for volume minimization; ii) scalable and adaptive algorithms towards online volume minimization; iii) validation, using existing (e.g., hyperspectral imaging) as well as promising new (e.g., document clustering) applications; and iv) theoretical aspects of the volume minimization formulation, focusing on fundamentals such as identifiability and performance bounds. Devising scalable volume minimization algorithms makes a lot of sense for modern sensing and clustering problems which involve rapidly increasing amounts of data. From an applications point of view, volume minimization for spectrum sensing, channel identification, and document clustering are completely new and challenging.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on (semi-)nonnegative matrix factorization using a simplicial cone model, which has a wide variety of applications in remote sensing (particularly hyperspectral imaging), radio frequency sensing for dynamic spectrum access, clustering, topic modeling, and social network analysis, to name a few.

 

Intellectual merit: Outcomes can be classified as contributions to i) theory, ii) algorithms, and iii) cross-disciplinary applications. In terms of theory, significant advances were made in terms of identifiability of the simplicial cone model using volume minimization, by developing new and connecting earlier identifiability conditions, resulting in the most relaxed identifiability conditions to date. Mixing theory and application, a fundamental link between nonnegative factorization and multivariate probability was explored, which in several important cases (e.g., Hidden Markov Model identification) naturally leads to solving factorization problems of the kind considered in this project. The proposed approach uses pair-wise co-occurrences of consecutive observable emission data and is thus very economical in terms of sample complexity. Another major methodological breakthrough was the combination of deep learning and latent clustering, published in Proc. ICML 2017, which has inspired much follow-up work. Nonlinearly distorted simplicial cone models were also considered, and identifiability guarantees with companion identification algorithms were obtained under certain conditions. These developments were fundamental and quite unexpected given the nature of these models. On the algorithms front, two new families of algorithms for volume minimization and structured matrix factorization were developed to effectively deal with robustness and scalability issues. A highly scalable stochastic optimization framework was designed to solve various matrix and tensor factorization problems, including the simplicial cone model with volume minimization. The proposed block-randomized stochastic proximal gradient descent (BR-SGD) framework is a novel combination of block randomized coordinate descent and stochastic proximal gradient. This algorithm has very lightweight updates and small memory footprint, which is well-suited for large-scale dense data factorization. BR-SGD is the first stochastic factorization framework for problems of this kind that offers scalability, flexibility and convergence guarantees. Under the applications and validation thrust, novel approaches to topic modeling and document clustering were considered and successfully tested with real data, showcasing the tangible benefits of identifiability in practice. For example, the proposed HMM identification technique was applied to topic modeling with word ordering information, which turned out to outperform methods that ignore such ordering information (i.e., the so-called bag-of-words model). Hyperspectral imaging was another seemingly very different application that was successfully considered, both in the classical setting and in `fusion? mode together with multispectral imaging. In both cases, important identifiability results and effective estimation algorithms were obtained.

 

Broader impacts: Research under this project was inherently multi-disciplinary, bringing together signal processing, factor analysis, optimization, data mining and machine learning to bear on problems in text, speech, and natural language processing, system identification, hyperspectral imaging, spectrum sensing / spectrum cartography, and other areas. In addition to spreading the word to the computer science and engineering communities, the PI has given talks to audiences in chemometrics, analytical chemistry, bioinformatics and biostatistics, where the simplicial cone model and volume minimization has great application potential. A well-cited tutorial overview article (Nonnegative Matrix Factorization for Signal and Data Analytics: Identifiability, Algorithms, and Applications) was written and published with support from this project ? and is quickly becoming a well-appreciated reference on the topic. The project partially supported a total of five PhD students (of whom two are female) and three postdoctoral associates over the years. Two of the students have graduated and now work as researchers in the US artificial intelligence / telecommunications industry. Two of the postdocs are now tenure-track faculty at major US research Universities.
